comments.body:
Two things (applicable to `openssl_privakey` and `openssl_publickey` too):
- why `import_tasks: ../tests/validate.yml` instead of `import_tasks: validate.yml`?
- why are validation tasks split in another file (`validate.yml`) and not kept in `main.yml`?

Apart from these minor points, it looks good to me.

@pilou- 

> why import_tasks: ../tests/validate.yml instead of import_tasks: validate.yml?

Because for some reason it can't find the proper path to the file if not specified that way.
This is the command I run:

```
#> source hacking/env-setup
#> ansible-test integration --docker=centos7 -v openssl_csr
```

> why are validation tasks split in another file (validate.yml) and not kept in main.yml?

To logically separate what is the scenario I am testing vs. the test suite to validate the scenario.

If this is a blocker I could revert, but if possible, I'd like to keep it that way
Could you leave one of the test with the previous interface, so we know it still does work. I've tried it locally and I know it works but so that test also shows (and ensure) that.

I'd rather remove the previous interface completely, because it is redundant.

Edit:
Openssl_certificate currently has a different interface, this PR allows using the same interface - I'd prefer the old one to be completely removed, since it is limited.

Agree but we can't do that from 2.4 to 2.5. In order to remove it cleanly we need to print warning message "Usage of commonName is deprecated and will be dropped in 2.6, please use subject: commonName".

Else people with a working playbook on 2.4, when they will update to 2.5 will have a broken playbook. I need to check with the community how many release notice we should be warning (if 1 we can drop it of 2.6, if 2 then it will be dropped in 2.7)

I mean, it states `This module is flagged as preview which means that it is not guaranteed to have a backwards compatible interface.`, but I agree that it would still be nice to at least have one version with a deprecation warning in the documentation.

Yeah, but even for preview modules people expect certain consistency between N and N+1 if it can be done. Here the code is actually backward compatible. The comment was more regarding the test and ensuring while we guarantee it we still maintain the soon to be legacy interface.
